home.content:
## The Mission
The mission of SHARP Dance Co. is to translate raw human emotion utilizing contemporary movement to connect the audience through individual interpretation.
## About SHARP
SHARP is a thirteen year old 501C-3 modern company and its theory of “meaning behind movement” is shown prominently throughout their work.  SHARP feels that dance should be more than a performance, it should be an experience.
SHARP has performed throughout the U.S. in cities such as:  New York, Rochester, Phoenix, Chicago, Cincinnati, Portland, Boulder, San Diego, Brooklyn, Portsmouth etc.  SHARP has toured throughout Europe in Italy, England and Greece.
Artistic Director/Choreographer Diane Sharp-Nachsin was selected as a New Edge Mix Artist Award Recipient in Philadelphia. She was also chosen as a BAU Institute fellow in June 2013 in Italy and an Artist in Residence recipient in Paros, Greece 2014.

bios.aboutDianeText:
Diane Sharp-Nachsin suffered from injuries that forced her to retire from performing, so in 2005 she founded SHARP and premiered the company in March 2006.  Diane’s work has been selected for the:  Cool NY Festival, Southern Vermont Dance Festival, STEPS Performance Lab (NY), Come Together Festival, Artsfest, Philadelphia International of the Arts (PIFA) and over 15 Fringe Festivals throughout the country and the United Kingdom.
Diane has been invited as a resident artist in the U.S. and abroad including: The Living Garden Residency (Greece), CEC New Edge Mix Residency (Philadelphia),  and the BAU institute Residency (Italy).  Diane’s choreography has been commissioned for Mid Atlantic Ballet, The prestigous Governors School, Penn State University and the New Zealand Embassy.
She started her career in Pittsburgh, dancing with Pittsburgh based, Mary Miller Dance Company from 1992-1994.  She returned to Philadelphia to dance on scholarship with Philadanco’s training program.  Diane has also danced professionally with Juan Antonio and dancers, Trapezius Aerial Dance Company, Deborah Birrane, Anne-Marie Mulgrew and Dancers, Convergence Dancers and Musicians/Dance Matrix and Amsterdam based company Jacqueline Knopps and dansers.  She has performed with Pennsylvania Ballet Theaters’ Principal dancers Leslie Carothers and Meredith Rainey and Dirk Platzik, formally of The White Oak Project with Mikhail Baryshnikov.
Some of Diane’s other original work has been showcased Maryland, Greece, Pittsburgh, Italy, California, New Hampshire, New York and Colorado and in numerous musicals throughout the Philadelphia Area.

headerBanner.title: Class Schedule
headerBanner.subtitle: Come dance with us
headerBanner.content:
SHARP is happy to announce we will now be opening our company class.
Classes will run 55 minutes. $10 cash or credit. Classes will be taught by a rotation of company members

media158.title: PUZZLE
media158.content: SHARP’s newest work premiered in November 2018, PUZZLE is a collaborative modern dance experience designed to piece together diverse life experiences and challenge the ingenuity of both the artists and audience.  Co-created by Joe Cotler, Koresh Dance Company Member and Diane Sharp-Nachsin, SHARP Dance Company’s Artistic Director, PUZZLE will be a combination of two: styles, ages and experiences all rolled into one exciting piece.

media159.content: “669” world premiered in November 2017.  It is a story of an amazing man Sir Nicholas Winton who saved 669 children from the Holocaust. The piece was created with amazing original music by Liliya Danieva from Moscow, Russia.

media160.title: Aquarian Exposition
media160.subtitle: A Trip Back to the Original Woodstock
media160.content: Aquarian Exposition: A Trip back to the Original Woodstock taps into the spirit of love, acceptance and exploration that made the hippie movement one that will transcend time.

sources.title: With a little help from your friends

media161.title: Seven Windows
media161.content: Based on the dream of a dancer in which she is visited by her recently departed mother, she asks her mother if she is in heaven. Her mothers’ response is that she has not opened the seven windows yet. The Seven Windows looks into the world of reincarnation and moving on in the afterlife. A collaborative project with with four fine artists from NYC, Massachusetts, Philadelphia & Italy.

media162.title: The Garden Tour
media162.content:
SHARP Dance Company will be presenting several dance pieces that intertwine the beauty of nature and the beauty of dance in one symbiotic art.  The pieces are designed to be performed in a park, garden or in various outdoor locations. No special flooring needed.

Engaging the Community with the Garden Tour: SHARP also offers unique and innovative ways to incorporate the community into our performance

sources.title: Garden tour with the Living Fountain

media163.title: Roller Coaster
media163.content: Haven’t we all heard the rules on a roller coaster ride.  Roller Coaster takes a fun look at listening or not listening to those rules. Voiceover Rich Orlow.

performers159.name: Greg Anmuth
performers159.bio:
Greg began his dance training at his mother’s studio in New Jersey; he then continued his education at Rowan University under the direction of Paule Turner and Melanie Stewart. He was elected the president of Rowan’s Contemporary Dance Company, and has been awarded the Bryna G. Goldhaft Medallion for Dance Excellence in 2012 upon his completion of his B.A. in Health and Exercise Science.  Now a co-owner of his family’s school, Greg has been awarded numerous choreography and entertainment awards.  Greg’s performance career has continued as a past company member with Band of Artists, Andrea Mychaels Dance Project, Roger Lee Dance, Nickerson-Rossi Dance (NRD) East Company and Legends in Concert.
This is Greg’s first season with SHARP Dance Company.

performers160.name: Hannah Brumbach
performers160.bio: Hannah Brumbach is a dancer and choreographer in the Philadelphia area.  She was raised and trained in Williamsport, Pennsylvania and continued her education at Eastern University earning a BA in Dance. Hannah’s performance career includes a 2016 solo work, “Cultivate”, choreographed by Lydia Bugosh, and performed at the American College Dance Association Festival. She has also staged three choreographic works at Eastern University and has restaged her largest work, “Hymn Study” at the 2017 “Bridgefest” in Cambria City.  Currently, Hannah fulfills her need to dance by teaching the next generation of movers and performing with Apex Dance Company and Melange Contemporary Dance Company.

performers161.name: Linnea Alexis Calzada-Charma
performers161.bio: Linnea began her dance education with Linda Moores, former principal dancer of Group Motion, and spent most of her training years at Mid-Atlantic Ballet in Newark, DE. She has had additional training at Central PA Youth Ballet, Pittsburgh Ballet Theatre School, Ballet Austin, The Rock School for Dance Education, Alonzo King's LINES Ballet, Secret Circus Philly: School for Contemporary Circus Arts, and was invited to dance with BalletX and Pennsylvania Ballet in 2015. Linnea graduated as a Dance Major from The University of the Arts in 2016, with honors and an Artist’s Merit Award Scholarship. Linnea has been dancing with SHARP for 6 years.

performers162.name: Sandra Davis
performers162.bio: Sandra is a native of Philadelphia and started her training at the Anastasi Dance Studio. She received her BFA in Ballet Performance from the University of the Arts in May of 2007. During her time at the University of the Arts, she studied under such instructors as: Christine Cox, Scott Jovovich, Andrew Pap, Eva Szabo, Ronen Koresh, and Kim Bears-Bailey. Sandra completed Philadanco's training program in August 2006. She also performed in Danco-on-Danco in September 2006 at the Painted Bride.  Sandra currently teaches at the Blue Bell School of Dance in Blue Bell, PA, and Mid-Atlantic Ballet in Newark, DE. She was named Artistic Director of Mid-Atlantic Ballet in June 2018. She began teaching ballroom dance for Dancing Classrooms Philly in September of 2014. Sandra started performing with SHARP in the spring of 2009.

performers163.name: Kate Lombardi
performers163.bio: Kate received her BFA from The University of the Arts, along with training at The Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance and the American Dance Festival. Kate is a member of SHARP, Dancefusion, and Anne Marie Mulgrew & Dancers in Philadelphia, where she enjoys both reconstructing historical works and exploring new choreography by local artists. Kate previously danced with Underground Dance Works and Between Movement Contemporary Dance Company. She was a guest artist with Esse Eficionado and joined Jeanne Ruddy Dance for its farewell season. Along with performing, Kate brings ballroom dance to the youth of Philadelphia as Managing Director for Dancing Classrooms Philly. Kate joined the SHARP family in January 2011.

performers164.name: Miguel Quinones
performers164.bio: Miguel began his Ballet training in Miami at the age of 7 at the Miami Conservatory.  Miguel also studied at Joe Michaels Studio with the New Image Dance Ensemble where he learned other forms of dance.  In college, at the New World School of the Arts in downtown Miami he continued his studies in jazz, modern and breaking.  After graduating in 3 years with honors, he joined the Parsons Dance Company in 2005.  He danced with David Parsons from 2005-2011 and currently is a guest dancer for the company. Miguel has worked with such artists as:  David Parsons, Robert Battle, Monica Bill Barnes, Donald McKayle, Michael Uthoff, Arthur Mitchell, Nicholas Andre, Mark Stuart, Shea Sullivan, Greg Dolbashian and other New York Artist.  He has taught master classes all over the U.S. and he is currently living in Philadelphia. He’s currently dancing with SHARP Dance Company and dances for Pages to Pirouettes, continuing his dance education, and focusing on creating more of his own choreography.

performers165.name: Rosemary Scalise
performers165.bio: Rosemary Scalise grew up dancing at local studios in her hometown of West Deptford, New Jersey. She was a member of the performing arts program at Paul VI High School under the direction of Courtney Daniels. Rosemary followed her passion to Towson University and earned her BFA in Dance Performance and Choreography in 2017. During her college career Rosemary performed original works by Darrell Grand Moultrie, Kim Y. Bears-Bailey, Runqiao Du, Linda-Denise Fisher-Harrell, Vincent Thomas, Quilan Arnold, and Susan Mann. Following graduation, Rosemary attended the 2017 METdance Professional Intensive in Houston, Texas. Rosemary now performs professionally in the Philadelphia area with Nickerson-Rossi Dance (East), Allegory Dance Theatre, Matter Movement Group, and other local artists.

apprentices166.name: Juliet Bernstein
apprentices166.bio: Juliet is a dance artist and performer originally from Los Angeles, CA where she began her formal dance training at Elements Dance Space. Juliet graduated from University of the Arts in Philadelphia, PA, where she earned her BFA in dance with a minor in musical theatre under the direction of Donna Faye Burchfield. She has been fortunate to work with various notable artists including, Bobbi Jean Smith, Gary Jeter, Juel D. Lane, Roni Koresh, and Sidra Bell. Her most recent debuts as a graduate include being a part of the upcoming feature film “Aviva” directed by Boaz Yakin and choreographed by Bobbi Jean Smith, performing in Roschman Dance Company’s 2018 season, and performing and working with choreographer Alisia Ialicicco in Mare Nostrum Elements Emerging Choreographer Series. Juliet is excited to be an apprentice this season with SHARP Dance Company!

guestPerformers167.name: Micah Geyer
guestPerformers167.bio: Raised in North Carolina, Micah started dancing at a young age with Nina's School of Dance in Durham. He later joined the North Carolina Youth Tap Ensemble under the direction of Gene Medler. During his career, he had the privilege to perform at the Kennedy Center and the Joyce Theater for Tap City, as well as tour throughout Europe and South America. He received his BFA in Dance Performance and Psychology from East Carolina University and joined Koresh Dance Company in 2007.

staff168.name: Nikki Battestilli
staff168.bio: Drexel University (2015), B.A. (Theater, Dance Minor) Robert E. Cook Honors College-Indiana University of Pennsylvania. Nikki has had the opportunity to work for numerous organizations such as: Brian Sanders JUNK, Pasion y Arte Flamenco, Eastern University, and Kids Across America. She recently left her position at Wolf Performing Arts Center where she was the Marketing and Development Director for 3 years. Nikki recently moved to Pittsburgh to take the position of Marketing Director with City Theatre. Nikki is incredibly grateful to be part of the SHARP family since January 2013 and can never leave.

staff169.name: Joe Cotler
staff169.bio: Joe grew up in Batavia, NY and trained at his mother Robin Cotler's dance studio, Images in Dance. He graduated from The University of the Arts in May 2009. While at school, he had the opportunity to work with numerous choreographers including Scott Jovovich, Roni Koresh and Paul Selwyn-Norton. He currently teaches and choreographs for numerous studios in the area and is a Koresh Dance company member. Joe has choreographed several pieces for SHARP Dance Company over the last 6 years.

staff170.name: Jenna Kueriz
staff170.bio: Jenna Kuerzi is an actor, singer, and deviser. She has worked regionally with Tribe of Fools (Barrymore Nominee: Best Ensemble/New Play- Fishtown: A Hipster Noir), 11th Hour, PlayPenn, Shakespeare in Clark Park, the Philadelphia Shakespeare Theatre, Philadelphia Young Playwrights, Irish Heritage Theatre, the Laurie Beechman Theatre in NYC, Act II Playhouse, and On the Rocks. Jenna's solo-ish show, Johnny Depp: A Retrospective on Late-Stage Capitalism, an original show she stars in and co-wrote with local playwright Val Dunn, traveled to the 2019 Edinburgh Fringe Festival. [www.jennakuerzi.com](//www.jennakuerzi.com)

staff171.name: Steven Vaughn
staff171.role: Guest Artist, Guest Choreographer, Former SHARP Dancer and Parsons Company Member
staff171.bio: Steven was born in Iowa City, Iowa, and grew up dancing all over the Midwest and Massachusetts at various dance studios. While attending the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, where he graduated with a BFA in Modern Dance in May 2009, he was given the opportunity to perform works by Silvanna Cardell, Martha Graham, and Twyla Tharp, among others, and to present his own choreography. His college career also afforded him the privilege of working professionally with Diane Sharp-Nachsin's SHARP Dance Company; Scott Jovovich in Brandywine Ballet Theater; Zane Booker and his Smoke, Lilies and Jade Arts Initiative; and Brian Sanders' JUNK. Steven joined Parsons Dance in June 2008 as an apprentice as was invited to become a company member this August 2009.  Steven has previously choreographed pieces on SHARP dance company and the Joffery Ballet summer program.

staff172.name: Kevin Ferguson
staff172.bio: Kevin is originally from Houston, Texas. He has studied at The Houston Ballet, Boston Ballet, The Ailey School, and graduated with a BFA from the Boston Conservatory of Music. Kevin is an NAACP and Arts Recognition and Talent Search recipient. He has taught and choreographed internationally and domestically. Kevin has performed work by Nilas Martins, Donald Byrd, and Larry Keigwin as a guest artist. He has danced with Elisa Monte Dance Company, Radio City, The Metropolitan Opera, Regis and Kelly, and David Parsons Dance Company. Kevin is proud to work with SHARP Dance.

quotes177.quote: …the gap between the audience age or level of appreciation for modern dance, choreographer Diane Sharp-Nachsin abridged it, capturing the free-form movements of concertgoers, but with an exciting, contemporary edge.
quotes177.author: Nicole Finkbinder

quotes178.quote: ..it seemed like there were more than just six dancers thanks to Sharp’s adept use of canons and different levels
quotes178.author: Kat Richter

quotes179.quote: SHARP Dance Company is quickly becoming recognized for their combination of inspired artistry, imagination capturing “stories of performance” and the discipline required of such performance mastery.
quotes179.author: Barry Livingstone

quotes180.quote: Pieces of U.........confronted the pains of discrimination through dance, multimedia, and prop.  The piece generated an uncomfortable and uneasy sensation, which was completely effective
quotes180.author: Kathleen Glynn

quotes181.quote: SHARP’s performance has emerged as a center piece of the Philly Fringe
quotes181.author: Lewis Whittington

quotes182.quote: ...the work tackles some weighty themes uncommon to the dance stage
quotes182.author: Lewis Whittington

quotes183.quote: …clean modern dance movement with a strong technique
quotes183.author: Jane Vranish

quotes184.quote: …expect a roller-coaster ride of emotions and life experiences
quotes184.author: Denise N. Lewis

press.author: Amherst-Lyndebrough-Milford-Mont Vernon-Wilton
press.description:
SHARP Dance Company is back at the Seacoast Fringe to perform 8 exciting pieces including excerpts from SHARP’s sold out sexy cabaret performance “Une Soiree au Cabaret” and the world premiere of “Beauty from Pain.”
SHARP Dance Company is a national touring modern dance company based out of Philadelphia that enjoys not only strong technical dance but incorporating that with various collaborators. SHARP’s striking work investigates the gravitational support each person is able to call upon in life.
Sexy and thought provoking, SHARP hopes to bring its kinetic energy to the Seacoast Fringe 2011. SHARP strives to bring together a company of strong dancers to perform work with a new vision. Their mission is to translate raw human emotion utilizing contemporary movement to connect the audience through individual interpretation.
This company and its theory of “meaning behind movement” is shown prominently throughout its work. SHARP feels that “dance should be more than a performance, it should be an experience. “
SHARP’s work was recently selected for The Phoenix Fringe Festival 2010, The Seacoast Fringe Festival 2010 & 2011, the Cool 2009 NY Festival, and The Fringe Wilmington Festivals in 2009, 2010 & 2011 and the 2011 Philadelphia Festival of the Arts (PIFA). Artistic Director Diane Sharp-Nachsin was selected as a New Edge Mix Artist Award recipient in Philadelphia, PA in 2008 and was commissioned to set work on the Mid-Atlantic Ballet in 2008- 2011.

press.author: Deni Kasrel
press.description: In a city where dance-theater rules, Diane Sharp-Nachsin calls her eponymous company the odd man out. "We don't tend to the performance-art side," she says — "we're more technically driven." Sharp Dance Co.'s gig is to translate human emotion into contemporary movement. Now in its fifth year, the troupe has gradually gained an enthusiastic fan base while also beefing up its roster, now 10 performers strong. "We like to have some nice and happy," says Sharp-Nachsin of her upcoming production, Revelation, "and also make you think." Hence such topics as female empowerment, the ravages of pollution ... and roller coasters.

press.author: Patrick Bresnyan
press.description:
Dance companies from around the Poconos and beyond will showcase their artistry at the Sherman Theater on Sunday for the 14th annual Mountain Dance Concert.

There will be 10 dance groups performing, and one of them is Sharp Dance Co. from Philadelphia. "Last year, we had the pleasure of performing at Mountain Dance Concert and we had a wonderful time," said Diane Sharp-Nachsin, artistic director and choreographer.

Sharp Dance Co. will perform "Unguarded Moment." "It is a solo done on pointe shoes in a straight-jacket. (It) tells the story of one girl's escape when no one was watching. Escaping from what is for the audience to decide," Sharp-Nachsin said.

press.author: Jennifer Feals
press.description:
PORTSMOUTH — Street performers, dancers, musicians, one-man acts and theater fans performed throughout the city Saturday as part of the inaugural Seacoast Fringe Festival.

With more than 30 world class acts slated to perform, the festival is a smaller model of the legendary month-long Edinburgh Fringe Festival — the oldest and largest in the world with more than 50,000 acts. The Seacoast Fringe Festival continues today, at venues throughout the city's downtown, with comedians, one-person plays, musicians, dancers and more. All venues are within walking distance of Market Square.

On the event Web site, organizers describe "fringe" as any creative, original performances that can be staged in front of an audience. The performances are further described as "Off-Broadway" or even "Off-Off-Broadway" by organizers as they are "out of the established mainstream."

"It's a chance to do the show and get it rolling," said Michael Trautman, of Portland, Maine, whose "Ping Pong: Inventive and hip clowning not just for kids" takes place at 5 p.m. at the Moffatt-Ladd House.

Trautman describes himself as a mime, clown, magician, juggler and storyteller whose family-friendly act is written for adults, but also enjoyed by children.

"I'm a one-man variety show," he said.

At Great Bay Academy of Dance on Saturday, the Sharp Dance Company of Philadelphia, Pa., highlighted performances on cultural, societal and environmental issues like water pollution and women's struggles.

The group's pieces offer much movement and technicality.

The group is not scheduled to perform today, but enjoys travelling to fringe festivals, Artistic Director Diane Sharp-Nachsin said. Five of the group's 10 dancers traveled to Portsmouth for the weekend festival.

"It's been really fun," she said. "We love the opportunity to be in Portsmouth."

press.author: Brittany Gonzales
press.description:
PHX: Fringe Welcomes SHARP Dance Co.

This month, prepare for downtown to be overrun. Don't worry, though, as this takeover will be at the hands of The Phoenix Fringe Festival and it's more 140 artists who will create 37 performances at six different venues. One such performance will come from SHARP, a modern dance company based in Philadelphia, Pa.

After a successful dance career, injuries forced Diane Sharp-Nachsin to end her time as a performer. “I was inspired by friends and fellow dancers to start my own dance company,” says Sharp-Nachsin who introduced the contemporary dance company, SHARP in 2005. The company currently consists of eight dancers — six of whom will be attending The Phoenix Fringe Festival (April 2-11) this year — a managing director, a resident lighting designer and a resident projection artist. SHARP performs regularly in Philadelphia and has a reputation of bringing large audiences to their performances. “We are a very tight group and love to spend time together on and off the dance floor,” says Sharp-Nachsin who is excited about the upcoming festival.

The Phoenix Fringe Festival is a non-profit organization that has a strong belief in live theater performances that are filled free-spirited artistic expression. This year, SHARP will be making it's first appearance at the festival and Sharp-Nachsin is excited to come to the West Coast and “experience some of the other companies that we would normally not get to see and to hopefully find a new audience that enjoys our work.” The dancers feel that a performance should be an experience and are hoping to illustrate this to the Phoenix audience through a piece called Pollution. According to Sharp-Nachsin, Pollution, “deals with worldwide water pollution and how it is a serious and disturbing issue. We are using movement, photos and text to help tell the story of what some people in the world have to deal with everyday.”

To be sure the company is prepared for performances, Sharp-Nachsin holds rehearsals on a regular basis. Rehearsals typically takes place on Sundays and involve reviewing past performances, teaching and learning new choreography and, most importantly, perfecting pieces. Some dancers have individual pieces that call for separate rehearsal times during the week and special attention from Sharp-Nachsin to ensure perfection. Since the group of dancers is very tight-knit, SHARP does not hold formal auditions. If the company is ever looking for an additional dancer, Sharp-Nachsin said she relies on the recommendations of her current dancers to find the perfect fit.

After SHARP's trip to Phoenix comes to an end, they will continue to work with guest choreographers and prepare for upcoming shows in New York, New Hampshire and Philadelphia. By the end of the year, SHARP will be obtaining their 501(c)3 status which will allow for more donations and grants that will open up opportunities for the group to travel both nationally and internationally. 

Feel it at www.sharpdance.org

press.author: Rob Kalesse
press.description:
CATCH "TISSUES AND RAZORBLADES" AT FRINGE WILMINGTON
Q: Can you tell us a little bit about your dance company's piece, titled "Tissues and Razorblades," which you'll be performing this coming weekend at the Fringe Wilmington festival?

A: I always have a hard time naming a show. We joke around and have a good time at rehearsal, but once we get on stage, we're very serious about our work. When you see this piece you're either going to want to cry or slice your wrists. All of the pieces in the show are very emotionally driven, so we expect you to be overcome with emotion.

Q: What about the show will make us feel emotional and perhaps shed a tear?

A: We're dealing with elements of religion, sexual discrimination, topics that hit home. But one piece that has gotten audiences crying in the past is about a woman not being able to have a baby and the emotional tale of what she is going through. There is an empty bassinet at the end, which leaves the perception of what is happening to the individual audience member.

Q: On your Web site, it says the Sharp Dance Company's goal is to establish "meaning behind movement." What do you mean by that?

A: I mean, dance should be more than a performance; it should be an experience. It should be addictive, full of uninhibited emotion, and it should move you. This is not just a bunch of bodies moving around on stage. It has more than that, it has to relay a story of some kind.

Q: How do you go about telling a story?

A: In addition to the choreography, we use the works of other local artists like digital projectionists, painters and photographers, to help tell the story. I feel like you possess a larger voice when you're working with other people and are bouncing ideas off of each other.

Q: Are any props used in the show?
A: Yes, as a matter of fact, one of the most interesting is a straight jacket. Our dancer starts out completely restricted and wrapped up in the jacket. Throughout the piece, she is slowly and eventually escaping from an insane asylum, with the straight jacket making that fact clear to the audience.
Q: A dancer, in pointe shoes, escaping from a straight jacket? Sounds like David Copperfield. A: Haha. Well, it's not a magic trick, but certainly requires a lot of balance and poise.
Q: You also mention how you like to employ "eccentric partnering" in your pieces. What is that?
A: I love to partner male and female dancers, for obvious reasons. When we do lifts, I try and input nontraditional pieces, where the female is perpendicular to floor as he spins her. It just makes the piece more exciting, eccentric, and more than just a typical cradle pose.
Q: What's your favorite part of the show?
A: To close the show, three dancers appear wrapped together in a 35-foot skirt. It's called "Blind Faith." It's something to see.

SHARP DANCE COMPANY
Hometown: Philadelphia
Artistic endeavor: "Tissues and Razorblades," an emotional and spiritual piece that strives to give "meaning behind movement" by transforming dance from a performance to an experience for the audience. Choreography mixes with other genres, such as photography, music and projection art, to convey stories of religion and discrimination.
Background: Diane Sharp-Nachsin, artistic director of Sharp Dance Company, danced professionally for several years in Pittsburgh before returning home to Philadelphia, where she started her own company in 2005.
Fringe Wilmington performance: Oct. 3 at 8:45 p.m., Oct. 4 at 12 p.m. at the baby grand.
Web site: www.sharpdance.org

Phoenix Fringe Teeters over the edge

Phoenix is about to be taken over by all strangeness that is performance art as six venues rally beneath a cloud of creative smoke kicked up by theater and dance troupes, solo artists and other entertainers. They're giving you Shakespeare and vaudeville acts, dance routines, monologues and more contemporary entertainment.
The Phoenix Fringe Festival was inspired by other popular events in cities throughout the US, which were in turn inspired by the original Edinburgh Fringe Festival - now the largest arts festival in the world.
The Phoenix festival is in its third year and will run, on Friday, simultaneously with First Friday. Events continue through Sunday, April 11.
"Last year there were 30 performers. This year we have 37, and we have also added the interactive art gallery from urbanSTEW, which is another 15 artists," said Daniel Roth, an ASU grad student who serves as the festival's director. "There's got to be 150 people working on the Fringe every day, some of them local and some of them coming nationally and internationally."
Indeed, the scope of what is available at this year's festival is impressive. Some examples:
Phoenix's Teatro Bravo is bringing a few laughs to the otherwise somber Space 55 by sticking four guys in a hotel room after one of them gets left at the altar. It's called "Dudes Gone Wild," and it's going to be loud, offensive and funny. Think stage version of "The Hangover."
At PHiX Art Space is Tempe's Aaron Wester's [OMIT], a play inspired by Dante's "Inferno," and the hilarious "Dinosaurs Exposed!"
Some of the out-of-town performances include the fusion "Tissues and Razorblades," by Philadelphia's dance company SHARP, and the play "My Rooster is Huge" from two-time Best in Fringe Festival at New York Antonio Sacre.
Want it weirder? Watch Brooklyn's Martin Dockery's "The Bike Trip" as he plays the Swedish pharmacologist who accidentally discovered LSD, or you can take in some risqué choreography that pokes fun at American culture in the "FDance Exposure." Or, not "watch" anything at all in the pitch-black performance "We Do it In The Dark."
"Violent Delights" shows that Shakespeare wasn't all about sappy sonnets or twisted trysts.
For something a little more real, "Live Out Loud" is about the homeless youth in Phoenix at the Tumbleweed Center for Youth Development.
This all begins the day before First Friday, and admission for each show is sold separately. Also, get down at one of the after-hour parties at Paisley Violin, Nine 05 and Lost Leaf.
Downtown Phoenix, Friday, April 2 to Sunday April 5 and Thursday, April 8 to Sunday, April 11, $5 to 15 per show
Tissues and Razorblades
Tissues and Razorblades, performed by the SHARP Dance Company, merges dance with other media including photography, set pieces and music.
College Times: How is SHARP unique?
Diane Sharp-Nachsin: SHARP Dance Company loves collaborating with other artists. We feel it expands our voice in a way working alone never could. In some of SHARP's current work you will see collaborations with photographer Kylene Cleaver, composer Jason Andrew, DJ/artist Geoff Partridge, voiceover artist Rich Orlow and resident projection artist Lauren Mandilian [among others]. A SHARP Dance Company performance is a multi-media event.
How did SHARP become involved in Phoenix Fringe?
SHARP has had the privilege of performing in The Philadelphia Fringe Festivals in 2007 and 2008 and the Inaugural Fringe Wilmington in 2009 in Delaware. We began researching other fringes around the country that we thought would be a good fit for SHARP. Once we saw the information on the PHX Fringe website with its juried selection process and the variety of artists we felt it was the perfect time to apply. We wanted to show our work to a Phoenix audience who we hope will enjoy a night of modern dance from a company with a different perspective from a different part of the country.
What is the show Tissues and Razorblades about?
Tissues and Razorblades is a collection of SHARP pieces. It uses the beautiful talent of seven professional dancers and the collaborative work of other artists from the Philadelphia area. Some of the work touches on serious issues in the world today including pollution, discrimination, mental illness and personal issues. In Tissues and Razorblades an audience will witness the raw emotion that exudes from SHARP's dancers as they weave their tales.
Why should people see the show?
SHARP is a modern dance company and its theory of "Meaning behind Movement" is showed prominently throughout their work. SHARP feels that dance should be more than a performance. It should be an experience. SHARP's pieces are an exciting blend of technically driven dance, intense themes and multi-media. In our performances we integrate various aspects of relationships and different events in one's life. We strive to accomplish this by incorporating weight-sharing partnering, creative progressions and unified material in our choreography.
Tissues and Razorblades will be performed at the Phoenix Theatre Little Theatre, Thursday, April 8 to Sunday, April 11, times vary, $10

press.author: Kathleen Glynn
press.description:
Etc. Performance Series premiered its Spring Showcase on Saturday, April 4th and Sunday, April 5th, at the Community Education Center on Lancaster Avenue.  The show was packed with dance, singing and acting talent, featuring works by Andre Jones, Elle, Elisha Halpin, Kate Speer, VADA Dance Collective, Kelly Adorno, SHARP Dance Company, SURGE Dance Team, IdRatherBeHere, and Etc. Performance Series director, Charles Tyson Jr.  The objective of the Etc. Performance Series is to provide “an opportunity for performance artists of any and all genres to show their work to a new and diverse audience in an intimate venue”, a goal which was successfully achieved this past weekend.
Toumbe (Let Us Pray), choreographed by Charles Tyson Jr. himself, opened the evening with a peaceful and content feeling.  The piece featured various jumps and turns, soft in dynamics, executed by two technically efficient dancers.  Elle consisted of three romantic songs sung by the artist Elle, the third of which was debuted from her new CD, Once Upon a Time.  Pieces of U, choreographed by Diane-Sharp Nachsin and performed by four members from SHARP Dance Company, confronted the pains of discrimination through dance, multimedia, and prop.  The piece generated an uncomfortable and uneasy sensation, which was completely effective. Undertow (in progress) was another duet choreographed by Elisha Clark Halpin, inspired Kate Chopin’s short story, “The Awakening”.  The dancing portrayed a struggle with control and physical and emotional manipulation.  Lullabies and Landmines, part of Vada Dance Collective’s repertoire, was choreographed by Katie Skettino.  The technically-demanding solo consisted of an eerily pleasant emotion and music.  Amino Acids, a work from IdRatherBeHere, was a brief theatrical work satirizing the stereotyped personas of actors and actresses.
After a ten minute intermission, the second half of Etc. Performance Series launched with another acting scene entitled Trust!  Directed by Charles Tyson Jr., the work played off of the complexities of straight and homosexual relationships.  Verbalized Ink, another theatrical work directed by Andre N. Jones, included brilliant rapping of contemporary political, spiritual and social issues.  An acting piece from IdRatherBeHere followed, Mominator.  This was a humorous exaggeration and spoof on the tendencies of mothers. The first dance piece of the second act and third dance duet of the evening, Window, was an exceptionally triumphant duet choreographed by Kelly Adorno.  The piece contained challenging partner work and a contrast of abrupt and delicate dynamics, which surprised the audience recurrently.  Flushed Spade, directed and performed by Lee Fogel and Kate Speer, was a silent scene depicting the delirium and mental chaos of small games, gambling, and competition.  With Hesitation, choreographed by Rebecca Moyer from Vada Dance Collective, involved a beautiful trio of both small individual solos and unison.  The movement highlighted exquisite extensions and overall quality of movement.  Boatman was a dance piece inspired by the journey to death and fatal accidents, performed by SHARP Dance Company with guest choreographer, Steven Vaughn.  Lastly, SURGE dance team and choreographer Kelly Snell added a bit of spice to the evening with a fun hip-hop routine.
Etc. Performance Series presents bi-monthly showcases and is quickly growing in popularity and participation.  Don’t miss out on the next show on Saturday, June 6th and Sunday, June 7th, 2009.

press.author: Lewis Whittington
press.description:
SHARP Dance Co., which has established itself in narrative dramatic dance in the past two years, celebrates its gay dancers by letting them express their stories onstage. Founder Diane Sharp-Nachsin likes to mix younger and older dancers and has choreographed seven segments for her work "Four on 2." which includes the end piece "Pieces of U."
Sharp-Nachsin says the theme is "about discrimination against people based on appearance and sexual orientation or religion. We collaborate with a photographer who shot street scenes of these perceptions... and our need to stop alienating each other."

press.author: Denise N. Lewis
press.description:
Mary Miller makes dance with something to say

For many people, an encounter with an angry motorist is an everyday annoyance. For Mary Miller, it was an inspiration: Facing road rage led the dancer and choreographer to create the Peace Project, a five-year exploration of peace through movement. The latest installment is Together, Mary Miller Dance Company's collaboration with Philadelphia-based SHARP Dance Company, with three shows Nov. 16-17, at Open Stage Theater.

Unlike a choreographer whose creative process begins in the studio, says Miller, "I start from the point of human experience and expand from there." Audiences get to relate, and even sometimes take part in, the performance. "There is a commonality among all of us; for example, we all want a good life," says Miller, her company's artistic director. "Dance is my voice, my language. So, I use dance to remind people of the connections we share."

The goal of connecting people extends to Miller Dance Company's collaboration with SHARP, an edgy modern and hip-hop dance group. The collaboration did not emerge from the blue: SHARP artistic director Diane Sharp-Nachsin was a dancer for Mary Miller from 1992-1996. Sharp-Nachsin, who formed her own company in 2005, echoes Miller's mission statement. "My work comes from having something to say," says Sharp-Nachsin. "It's not just arbitrary movement in the middle of the floor."

Both companies prize unpredictability. "A big part of creativity is humor," says Miller. "I am moved by issues that present themselves to be funny. And I'm not preachy. I approach it as, 'I'm thinking about this, what do you think?'"

The Nov. 16 and 17 performances here also feature local guest artists including musician Ellen Gozion, spoken-word artist Vanessa German, and musician and performance artist Stephen Pellegrino.

Looking ahead, Miller and Sharp-Nachsin hope that this year's collaboration will be one of many. They intend to broaden their audience by reprising Together in Philadelphia.

Meantime, audiences for Together here should expect a roller-coaster ride of emotions and life experiences. Miller's works include a dance about the experience of dreaming. Sharp-Nachsin's sensual dance "Linear" tells the story of a woman who's living life on the straight and narrow until a love interest has her stepping out of her comfort zone. Perhaps audiences who connect with the work on stage will have a better chance of connecting with one another, as well.

Mary Miller Dance Company presents Together 8 p.m. Fri., Nov. 16; and 2 and 8 p.m. Sat., Nov. 17. Open Stage Theater, 2835 Smallman St., Strip District. $18 ($15 seniors/$10 students/$5 students Nov. 17 matinee). 412-394-3353 or www.MaryMillerDanceCo.org

Best Bets!
Wilmington on the fringe. Une Soiree au Cabaret at Fringe Wilmington 2011 presented at 8 p.m. Saturday with Sharp Dance Company at the Christina Cultural Arts Center. A step back in time to early-1900s France, with a collaboration in dance, digital projection, and live vocals.
Christina Cultural Arts Center, 705 N. Market St., Wilmington. Admission: $5. Information: 302-932-0738 or 302-332-2407, www.sharpdance.org.

Do This!
Wilmington on the fringe
Une Soiree au Cabaret at Fringe Wilmington 2011 will be presented at 8:30 p.m. Friday and 8 p.m. Saturday with Sharp Dance Company at the Christina Cultural Arts Center, 705 N. Market St., Wilmington, Del. Sharp takes the audience a step back in time to early-1900s France, with a full night of material from the Wilmington Fringe Festival 2011. The night will showcase a collaboration in dance, digital projection, and live vocals with a sexy, wicked, and comical cabaret spirit. Admission: $5. Information: 302-932-0738 or 302-332-2407, http://www.sharpdance.org
